deliberation: I considered whether the divorce and sale language is literal or metaphorical. The historical situation is exile, but no literal divorce document or financial creditors are in view; instead the familial and commercial images are applied to the covenant relationship. I also considered whether 'mother' is literal or symbolic; in prophetic diction it often stands for Zion/Jerusalem as the mother of the people.

instances.english_text: the bill of divorce of your mother whom I dismissed
vehicle: bill of divorce dismissing a wife
ground: formal severing of an intimate bond
instances.explanation: God’s distancing of Himself from Zion/Israel is portrayed as issuing a formal divorce document to their ‘mother’, a metaphor for the covenant community/city.

instances.english_text: which of My creditors was it to whom I sold you off?
target: Israel’s being handed over to foreign powers
vehicle: sale of children to a creditor
ground: loss of freedom due to obligation
posture: denial of any external constraint on God
instances.explanation: Exile or subjugation is depicted as a father selling children to a creditor; the ‘creditor’ stands metonymically for foreign oppressors, while the whole is a metaphor for God’s judicial handing over.

instances.english_text: You were sold off for your sins
ground: loss of status and freedom as consequence of liability
being given over as a penalty
instances.explanation: Their suffering is described as ‘being sold’, a metaphor mapping commercial enslavement onto the theological reality of judgment for sin.

instances.english_text: your mother was dismissed for your crimes
target: withdrawal of divine protection from Zion/Jerusalem
ground: expulsion from the household because of offense
instances.explanation: Zion/Jerusalem, personified as their ‘mother’, is said to be ‘sent away’ as a wife is dismissed, extending the divorce metaphor to link their crimes with her expulsion.

deliberation: I checked whether the question about God’s arm is literal or an idiomatic anthropomorphism expressing power. I also weighed whether the drying of sea and rivers is a literal reference to past miracles (Exodus) or hyperbolic imagery for His capacity. The language of ‘arm’ and ‘rebuke’ clearly functions metaphorically/idiomatically for power exercised through command.

instances.english_text: Is my arm, then, too short to rescue
vehicle: a short human arm unable to reach
ground: inability to reach and pull someone to safety
instances.explanation: ‘Arm’ is a standard biblical metaphor for power, and ‘short’ is idiomatic for ‘insufficient’; God denies that His saving power is limited like a too-short human arm.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן בְּגַעֲרָתִי אַחֲרִיב יָם אָשִׂים נְהָרוֹת מִדְבָּר
instances.english_text: With a mere rebuke I dry up the sea, And turn rivers into desert
target: extent of God’s sovereign power over creation and history
vehicle: instant desiccation of sea and rivers by a spoken rebuke
instances.explanation: Whether alluding to Exodus or not, the language functions hyperbolically to stress that a single divine command can obliterate mighty waters—an extreme image to assert limitless power.

instances.hebrew_text: תִּבְאַשׁ דְּגָתָם מֵאֵין מַיִם וְתָמֹת בַּצָּמָא
instances.english_text: Their fish stink from lack of water; They lie dead of thirst
target: total devastation resulting from God’s judgment
vehicle: fish rotting and dying of thirst in dry waterways
ground: complete, even absurd reversal (water creatures dying of thirst)
posture: graphic intensification to drive home the warning
instances.explanation: The picture of aquatic creatures dying of thirst is deliberately extreme and paradoxical, heightening the portrayal of how devastating God’s intervention could be.

deliberation: I considered whether this is literal cosmic darkness or figurative language. The clothing verbs applied to the heavens and the mention of sackcloth clearly personify the skies and invoke mourning imagery, a common prophetic trope.

instances.hebrew_text: אַלְבִּישׁ שָׁמַיִם קַדְרוּת וְשַׂק אָשִׂים כְּסוּתָם
instances.english_text: I clothe the skies in blackness And make their raiment sackcloth
vehicle: putting dark garments and sackcloth on a person
ground: external appearance expressing grief and gloom
instances.explanation: The skies are personified as someone being dressed, and their ‘clothing’ is blackness/sackcloth, a metaphor casting cosmic darkness as mourning garb under divine action.

deliberation: I checked whether ‘tongue of the taught/disciples’ is purely literal or a metonymic way to speak of teaching capacity, and whether ‘rouses my ear’ is more than a physical waking up. Both expressions use body parts metaphorically for capacities and dispositions toward God’s word.

instances.hebrew_text: נָתַן לִי לְשׁוֹן לִמּוּדִים לָדַעַת לָעוּת אֶת־יָעֵף דָּבָר
instances.english_text: gave me a skilled tongue, to know how to speak timely words to the weary
target: the servant’s God-given capacity to instruct and comfort
ground: ability to articulate fitting, learned speech
instances.explanation: ‘Tongue of limmudim’ uses the tongue metonymically for speech and metaphorically as the instrument of a trained disciple, conveying divinely taught eloquence for helping the weary.

instances.hebrew_text: יָעִיר בַּבֹּקֶר בַּבֹּקֶר יָעִיר לִי אֹזֶן לִשְׁמֹעַ כַּלִּמּוּדִים
instances.english_text: Morning by morning, [God] rouses me, rousing my ear to give heed like disciples
target: ongoing responsiveness of the servant to divine instruction
vehicle: rousing/waking up the ear each morning
ground: being made attentive and alert to hear
transition from passivity to listening engagement
instances.explanation: The ‘ear’ stands metonymically for the capacity to listen and obey; God is said to ‘rouse’ it like waking a sleeper, a metaphor for cultivating a disciple’s attentiveness.

deliberation: I assessed whether ‘opened my ears’ is physical or idiomatic. In prophetic texts it often signifies enabling obedience. The rest of the verse (‘I did not rebel’) confirms that the opening is figurative for responsive obedience.

instances.english_text: My Sovereign GOD opened my ears
target: the servant’s capacity and willingness to heed God
vehicle: removing a blockage from a bodily organ
ground: transition from inability/unwillingness to active hearing
instances.explanation: The ‘ear’ stands for obedience; God ‘opening’ it is an idiomatic metaphor for enabling the servant to listen and not rebel.

deliberation: Most of the verse may describe literal or at least realistically imaginable abuse of the servant. I looked for any figurative devices; the key candidate is the use of ‘face’ as the locus of shame, likely functioning as a synecdoche for the whole person’s experience of humiliation.

instances.english_text: I did not hide my face from insult and spittle
target: the servant’s whole self enduring shame without retreat
vehicle: not hiding one’s physical face from public indignities
ground: refusing to avoid or evade humiliation
staying present in the place of shame
instances.explanation: The ‘face’ functions as a synecdoche for the whole person in the social space of shame; maintaining an uncovered face represents the servant’s refusal to flee humiliation.

deliberation: I looked especially for explicit comparison markers. The phrase ‘set my face like flint’ uses the comparative particle כְּ and is a stock simile for resolute determination.

instances.english_text: I have set my face like flint
target: the servant’s unwavering resolve in the face of opposition
vehicle: very hard stone used for tools
ground: hardness, resistance to being shaped or broken
posture: positively valuing steadfastness under God’s help
instances.explanation: The servant’s ‘face’ symbolizes resolve; comparing it to flint vividly depicts inflexible, unbreakable determination, an idiomatic simile for steadfast courage.

deliberation: Here the dominant motif is legal. I examined how far the courtroom imagery extends: ‘my vindicator’, ‘who contends with me’, ‘baʿal mishpati’. These expressions metaphorically place the servant’s situation in a lawsuit setting to convey justification.

instances.english_text: My Vindicator is at hand
target: God’s act of declaring the servant in the right
vehicle: a legal advocate who vindicates a client in court
ground: someone who secures a favorable verdict
posture: confident reliance on God’s legal advocacy
instances.explanation: God is portrayed as ‘my vindicator’, a legal metaphor casting Him as the one who will secure the servant’s acquittal in a figurative courtroom.

instances.english_text: Who would be my opponent? (lit. “who is the owner of my lawsuit, let him approach me”)
target: any accuser challenging the servant’s legitimacy
vehicle: the ‘owner’ of a lawsuit approaching in court
instances.explanation: Calling an adversary ‘baʿal mishpati’ frames opposition as a court case; the legal metaphor underscores that, with God as Vindicator, no plaintiff can succeed.

deliberation: I noted the explicit comparison ‘like a garment’ and the image of moths consuming opponents. The first is a simile, the second extends the clothing image as a metaphor for the slow, inevitable ruin of the accusers.

instances.english_text: They shall all wear out like a garment
target: the eventual demise and fading of the servant’s adversaries
vehicle: an old garment decaying from use
posture: minimizing their apparent power by stressing their frailty
instances.explanation: The enemies’ end is likened to a garment that naturally wears out, a simile emphasizing their impermanence and fragility.

instances.english_text: The moth shall consume them
target: the destruction of the servant’s opponents
ground: silent, often unseen but thorough destruction
inevitable nibbling away until nothing remains
posture: portraying their downfall as certain and almost contemptible
instances.explanation: By extending the clothing image, the text metaphorically portrays adversaries as garments eaten by moths, highlighting the quiet inevitability of their ruin.

deliberation: I evaluated whether the ‘walking in darkness’ is literal or a stock metaphor; in wisdom and prophetic literature it regularly describes distress or lack of guidance. I also examined ‘trust in the name of YHWH’ as potential metonymy, where ‘name’ stands for God’s revealed character.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר הָלַךְ חֲשֵׁכִים וְאֵין נֹגַהּ לוֹ
instances.english_text: Though walking in darkness and having no light
target: the believer’s experience of trouble, perplexity, or lack of perceptible guidance
vehicle: walking in physical darkness with no light
ground: inability to see the way, vulnerability, uncertainty
lack of clarity about the path ahead
posture: setting context for exhortation to trust
instances.explanation: ‘Walking in darkness’ is an idiomatic metaphor for living in a state of distress or lack of guidance, yet still being called to trust God.

instances.english_text: Let them trust in the name of GOD
target: trust in God Himself—His character and promises
vehicle: reputation/renown as stand-in for the person
ground: the name encapsulates identity, character, and authority
to rely on the name is to rely on the person behind it
posture: directing faith to God’s revealed character
instances.explanation: ‘Name’ stands metonymically for God’s revealed character and reliability; trusting in His ‘name’ means depending on who He is and what He has promised.

deliberation: I examined whether the fire imagery is literal or figurative. Within the context (contrasted with trusting God’s name), the ‘fire’ and ‘firebrands’ are best taken as metaphors for self-made guidance or schemes. The imperative ‘walk in the light of your fire’ functions ironically, leading to ‘lying down in pain’—a darkly ironic reversal.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן כֻּלְּכֶם קֹדְחֵי אֵשׁ מְאַזְּרֵי זִיקוֹת
instances.english_text: But you are all kindlers of fire, girding on firebrands
target: those who rely on their own schemes or sources of illumination instead of God
vehicle: people who ignite and strap on torches/firebrands
ground: creating and carrying one’s own light rather than depending on a given source
posture: critical exposure of self-made ‘light’ as negative
instances.explanation: Those addressed are pictured as people who kindle and gird firebrands, a metaphor for manufacturing their own guidance or security instead of trusting God.

instances.hebrew_text: לְכוּ בְּאוּר אֶשְׁכֶם וּבְזִיקוֹת בִּעַרְתֶּם ... לְמַעֲצֵבָה תִּשְׁכָּבוּן
instances.english_text: Walk by the blaze of your fire, by the brands that you have lit! … You shall lie down in pain
target: the outcome of self-reliant, God-neglecting choices
vehicle: walking by one’s own firelight and then lying down in torment
a journey guided by self-made fire ending in painful rest
ground: trusting in self-generated ‘light’ leads to a harmful end
instances.explanation: The command to ‘walk in the light of your fire’ is ironic: those who follow their own light will ‘lie down in pain’. The fire imagery metaphorically represents self-derived guidance culminating in torment.
